up.name: Up Quark
up.info: Lightest quark, found in protons and neutrons

down.name: Down Quark
down.info: Second lightest quark, essential for nuclear stability

charm.name: Charm Quark
charm.info: Second generation quark, found in J/ψ meson

top.name: Top Quark
top.info: Heaviest elementary particle, as heavy as a gold atom!

bottom.name: Bottom Quark
bottom.info: Also called 'beauty', important for CP violation studies

electron.name: Electron
electron.info: First elementary particle discovered, makes chemistry possible

tau_neutrino.name: Tau Neutrino
tau_neutrino.info: Last Standard Model particle to be directly observed

photon.name: Photon
photon.info: Quantum of light, mediates electromagnetic force

w_boson.name: W Boson
w_boson.info: Mediates weak force, causes beta decay

higgs.name: Higgs Boson
higgs.info: Gives mass to other particles, Nobel Prize 2013

sections.title: Elementary Particle Physics
sections.subtitle: A Journey from the Universe to Its Smallest Building Blocks
sections.demo_text:
Welcome to an interactive exploration of the fundamental nature of reality.
Scroll down to begin your journey through scales, particles, and forces.

cards.title: From Cosmos to Quarks: A Journey of Scale
content: The universe spans an incredible range of scales. From the observable universe at 10²⁶ meters to the smallest meaningful length (Planck length) at 10⁻³⁵ meters, we traverse 61 orders of magnitude!

content.text: Each step down in scale reveals new physics:

items: 10⁻¹⁰ m (Atomic): Electron orbitals, chemistry happens here
10⁻¹⁵ m (Nuclear): Strong force dominates, quarks confined
10⁻¹⁸ m (Deep inelastic): Quarks behave as free particles

content.text: The de Broglie wavelength sets the quantum scale:
When λ ≈ size of system, quantum mechanics is essential!

cards.title: Memory Trick: Powers of Ten
content: Mega (10⁶), Kilo (10³), Hecto (10²), Deca (10¹), Centi (10⁻²), Milli (10⁻³), Micro (10⁻⁶), Nano (10⁻⁹), Pico (10⁻¹²)

cards.title: The Atomic Theory Evolution
content: For centuries, we believed atoms were indivisible - the word literally means "uncuttable" in Greek. But the discovery of radioactivity in 1896 changed everything!
Today we know that atoms consist of:
list_items: Empty space: 99.9999999999996% of an atom is empty!

items: 1911: Rutherford's gold foil experiment reveals the nucleus

content.title: CERN Connection
content.text: The Large Hadron Collider recreates conditions from 10⁻¹² seconds after the Big Bang, when quarks roamed free before being confined into protons and neutrons!

cards.title: The Standard Model: Nature's LEGO Set
content: All matter and forces (except gravity) arise from just 17 fundamental particles. Think of them as nature's LEGO blocks!

cards.title: Memory Trick: Particle Categories
content: Fermions (matter particles): "Frankly, Every Real Material Is Obviously Numerous"
